title.narrative: Caritas Haiti Rapid Response to support communities affected by the 2021 earthquake EA17-2021

description.narrative:
A 7.2-magnitude earthquake quake struck 8 km (5 miles) from the town of Petit Trou de Nippes on August 14th 2021, about 150 km west of the capital Port-au-Prince, at a depth of 10 km, the USGS said. The earthquake is potentially bigger and shallower than the magnitude 7 earthquake that struck Haiti 11 years ago, killing tens if not hundreds of thousands of people, flattening buildings and leaving many homeless.
Area most affected: southwestern part of the island, including the cities of Les Cayes and Jeremie and the surrounding area - these are the same communities affected by Hurricane Matthew in 2016. There is a very unstable situation in terms of civil unrest and gang activity - this has increased after the assassination of the president in July. Traditionally a very poor area of the island, 80% unemployment rate in the past and highly food insecure
As of 25th August there have been more than 2200 deaths, at least 130,000 houses damaged or destroyed, and at least a million people affected. Most pressing needs: Shelter; WASH; food; medical care; medicines.
Caritas Haiti are planning a 2 month rapid response, 1 Sep – 31 Oct 2021, with a budget of 241,566 Euros.
The response will target 1400 HHs (10,000 people) who have been affected by the earthquake and will be implemented by the Diocese of Cayes, Diocese of Jérémie, Diocese of Anse-à-Veau/Miragoane - under the coordination of Caritas Haiti.
The response will focus on providing food kits, hygiene kits, water, health kits and PPE.
